Abstract: Current challenges demand a profound restructuration of the global healthcare system. One possible approach to meet this demand is a laterally distributed platform such as the Internet of Things (IoT). Real-time motion metrics in PD could be obtained virtually in any scenario by placing lightweight wearable sensors in the patient's clothes and connecting them to a medical database through mobile devices such as cell phones or tablets. Technologies exist to collect huge amounts of patient data not only during regular medical visits but also at home during activities of daily life. These data could be fed into intelligent algorithms to first discriminate relevant threatening conditions, adjust medications based on online obtained physical deficits, and facilitate strategies to modify disease progression. Abstract: Parkinson's disease is one of the most common neurodegenerative diseases. We position encode the triple scale features and classify the gait severity of PD patients based on MDS-UPDRS. Abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder primarily affecting elderly people. In addition, Mendelian inheritance patterns are seen in about 5% of cases. In this study we aimed to assess the significant correlation between the development of PD with individual's family's neurological health history. Here we have considered total 13 specific questionnaire related to the subject's neurological family history. The statistical attribution has been made for both uncategorized and categorized by sex. There are notable correlations observed between the PD patient and the history of neurological disorders in family members. Here, we saw that most of them-such as anxiety, depression, Alzheimer's disease, and Parkinson's disease-are protective in nature, while very few-such as the multiple sclerosis (OR-3.25) of the paternal grandmother, the dystonia (OR-1.92) maternal grandmother, and the schizophrenia (OR-1.65) of the mother-act as risk factors. These figures also demonstrate how important family history is in determining the likelihood that the next generation will develop Parkinson's disease.

Timely and precise diagnosis of PD is of paramount importance, enabling early interventions and enhancing overall patient care. The presented work focuses on non-invasive detection of PD through voice analysis, targeting early intervention. Dysphonic voice patterns, indicative of PD progression, are analyzed using advanced signal processing and machine learning. Methodology involves collecting voice recordings from PD-affected individuals and healthy controls, with rigorous analysis of acoustic features. This approach minimizes patient discomfort and reduces healthcare costs, potentially revolutionizing PD care and enhancing patient quality of life. This study explored the efficacy of 4 machine learning models - Decision Trees, k-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Machine, and Naive Bayes- in Parkinson's Disease (PD) detection. k-Nearest Neighbors classifier demonstrates much better performance compared to the other three, achieving an accuracy of 96.61%.

Abstract: Freeze of Gait (FoG) and falls are two common episodic Parkinson's disease symptoms. Devices based on wearable sensors can detect FoG and generate a cue to prompt the user to start walking again. This paper presents a system consisting of sensor-based wearable smart shoes for monitoring and detecting FoG in Parkinson's Disease (PD) patients. The system also identifies the occurrence of fall and notifies caretakers regarding the same. The left leg shoe has been designed to detect FoG and right leg shoe for fall detection. The device uses EMG sensors to detect muscular contraction, FSRs to determine the change in foot pressure, Inertial Measurement Unit to detect the fall, microcontrollers, Wifi module, and the Blynk app to display the data regarding occurrence of FoG and detection of fall. Visual and vibratory cues using laser and vibration motors are provided to the patient to overcome FoG.

Abstract: Monitoring motor function of patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) over long periods of time is essential in order to improve symptom management and avoid complications. Wearable technologies can be useful in this context as long as they do not unnecessarily increase patient and caregiver burden. The goal of the current study was to identify whether using more wearable sensors improved the estimation of whole-body bradykinesia scores. Ten patients diagnosed with idiopathic PD were recruited to take part in this study. Data was collected over 3 separate occasions using clinical evaluations and three-axis acceleration. In order to estimate the clinical scores associated with bradykinesia of the upper-and lower-limbs, a machine learning algorithm using a leave-one-subject-out cross-validation paradigm was implemented. Using two sensors per limb did not improve estimation error within the upper-or lower-limbs. Results demonstrate that the use of multiple sensors on a single limb does not significantly improve the estimation of clinical scores related to bradykinesia. However, in order to obtain whole-body limb-specific bradykinesia scores, a minimum of one wearable sensor per limb is required.

Abstract: The primary manifestations of Parkinson Disease (PD) concern abnormalities of movement associated with the constant deterioration of motor skills. Such motor impairment affects patients' movement accuracy and coordination, disrupting their daily life. Taking into account recent studies stating that computer-based physical therapy games can be used as a PD rehabilitation option, we propose a novel Exergame, the iPrognosis Warming up Game (http://www.i-prognosis.eu/), as a user-friendly tool that could both serve as a computer-based physical therapy game, as well as a means of accurately and automatically identifying the severity of PD motor symptoms.
